entry.title: From Customer Org. Chart to SAP Org. Structure
entry.content:
Hello SAP Gurus,
While diving deep into the world of SAP ERP for over 10 years, I wanted to share some of my findings and experience on a topic that can be a challenge for many of us: How to Design the Customerâ€™s Organization Hierarchy into SAP Enterprise Structure.

It's great to deploy what the SAP best practice says, but from the customer perspective itâ€™s very sensitive step as itâ€™s reflecting the overall business decisions. I recognized this during my career in implementing SAP projects, and I hope my findings can help you out there for whom might be starting on a similar journey.

Bridging the Gap Between Customer's Org. Chart and SAP Enterprise Structure

We all have our company's organizational chart hanging somewhere in the office or in a PowerPoint file. It shows the customer's department hierarchy, who reports to whom, and how teams are structured.

But how do we take that familiar hierarchy and map it to SAP's world of Company Codes, Plants, and Purchasing Organizations? It's not always a one-to-one match, and that's where the complexity (and honestly, the fun!) begins.

I found an example of this in old SAP Community question from 2008. A community user laid out a detailed case study of a company with 4 factories, 3 regional distribution centers, 15 sales offices, in addition of an R&D team and project management team. It was a fantastic real world scenario that highlighted the tough question we often face.

"since material from Plant and RDC is being transferred to Branches and from there it is distributed to customers therefore the valuation of FG at BRANCH and RDC should be different as transportation cost, packing, unpacking etc cost should get added at Branch level. Therefore in case I make branch as Storage location, I will miss the valuation part while if I make them as Plant then there will be lot of documents get generated for each movement."

This is exactly the kind of practical dilemma that gets to the heart of enterprise structure design. It's a constant balancing act between financial accuracy and operational efficiency.

Understanding The SAP Organizational Units

Before we define and assign the SAP enterprise structure, we need to know exactly what of each SAP org. unit represents. Itâ€™s helpful to think of them in a hierarchical way, starting from the top.

  1. Client: the highest level in the SAP system hierarchy. Specifications that you make, or data that you enter at this level are valid for all company codes and for all other organizational structures. You therefore only need to make these specifications, or enter this data once. This ensures that the data is consistent.
  2. Company Codes: is the central organizational unit of external accounting within the SAP System. You must define at least one company code before implementing the Financial Accounting component. The business transactions relevant for Financial Accounting are entered, saved, and evaluated at company code level.
  3. Plant: organizational unit serving to subdivide an enterprise according to production, procurement, maintenance, and materials planning aspects. It is a place where either materials are produced or goods and services provided.
  4. Purchasing Organizations and Purchasing Groups: An organizational unit subdividing an enterprise according to the requirements of Purchasing. It procures materials and services, negotiates conditions of purchase with vendors, and is responsible for such transactions. A purchasing group is a key for a buyer or group of buyers in SAP ERP. It is responsible for the procurement of a material or class of materials, and is the principal channel for a company's dealings with its suppliers.

Organizational Unit

Key Characteristics

Typical Use Cases

Client

Highest level, represents entire corporate group

One per SAP system

Company Code

Legal entity with independent financial statements

Subsidiaries, country operations

Plant

Operational unit where business activities occur

Factories, warehouses, sales offices

Storage Location

Physical storage area within a Plant

Warehouse sections, storage areas

Purchasing Org

Defines procurement scope and authority

Centralized or decentralized procurement

Purchasing Group

Actual procurement team or buyer

Commodity teams, regional buyers

A Visual Approach to Mapping

I'm a visual learner, so diagrams really help me solidify these concepts. I've created a couple of diagrams to illustrate how a typical departmental structure might map to SAP organizational units, and how those units relate to each other.
Here's a conceptual mapping from real-world departments to SAP units:

And here's a more detailed example of what a complete SAP organizational hierarchy might looks like, incorporating multiple company codes, plants, and purchasing organizations:

My Key Takeaways and Learned Lessons

After implementing a lot of SAP projects, here are some advices I have heard from my leaders:

Start with the "Why," Not the "What." Don't just create organizational units because they exist in your company. Think about your business processes and reporting requirements first. What do the customer need to see in his financial reports? How he manage his inventory? How do he want to analyze his procurement activities and expenses? The answers to these questions should guide you WHAT is the correct design decisions.

  1. The Plant is probably the most versatile org. unit in SAP. I've seen Plants used to represent everything from manufacturing facilities to service centers. Don't be afraid to think creatively about how to use Plants to model your business operations. Just remember that each Plant needs to be assigned to a Company Code, so plan accordingly. And remember that SAP defines the plant as a logistics organizational element that is used by all the logistics modules. The plant is assigned to a company code that may have many plants assigned to it. A plant is typically configured in conjunction with the company code and valuation area due to tax rules and regulations.
    Depending on the role the plant has in the organization, a plant can be defined for the following purposes:
    • In Sales and Distribution (SD), a location from which finished goods and materials are stored and distributed.
    • A location from which services are rendered.
    • Materials Management (MM), a location where material flow is managed and stock requirements are managed from both the inbound and outbound perspectives.
    • A location where material stock is consumed, planned, and purchased.
    • A manufacturing facility where materials are produced, as in Production Planning (PP).
  2. Purchasing org. structure has a huge impact on your procurement processes, approval workflows, and reporting. I learned that the hard way when we had to redesign our purchasing structure because we hadn't thought through the implications properly. Take time to understand whether a centralized or decentralized org. unit makes the most sense for your company.
  3. Plan for Growth and Change, Your first design probably won't be perfect, and your business will expand over time. Build flexibility into your design where possible, and don't be afraid to iterate, I've seen too many implementations get stuck because they tried to create the "perfect" structure from day one instead of starting with something good and improving it over time.
  4. Document Your Decisions, This might seem obvious, but document not just what you designed, but why you designed it. think in future questions, when someone ask why the regional sales offices are defined as plants instead of storage locations, you'll be glad that you wrote your reasoning.

Important Considerations

in past implementations i've encountered some comments from the customer that might help you think through your own design:

  1. Multi-Country Operations: If the customer operates in multiple countries, you'll likely need separate company codes for each country due to legal and tax requirements, but you might be able to share plants across company codes for operational efficiency.
  2. Shared Transactions: If the customer has shared service centers (like a centralized IT department or shared warehouse), think carefully about how to define and assign these on SAP, sometimes they're best represented as separate org. units, sometimes as cost centers within existing org. units.
  3. Acquisitions and Divestitures: If the company invest in other legal entities by frequently acquires or divests business units, design the SAP structure to make these transitions easier, this might mean keeping acquired companies as separate company codes initially, even if the customer plan to integrate them later.

Summery

SAP Enterprise Structure design is a piece of art, a part of business administration science, and a part of overall company growth.
There's no one "correct" way to do it, but there are definitely wrong ways, the key here is to understand customer business requirements, think through the implications of your design, and be prepared to adapt as you may learn later.

I hope my thoughts and findings has been helpful for you, and I'm always learning new things about SAP organizational structures, so I'd love to hear your thoughts and experiences.

  • What challenges have you faced when mapping customer's organization in SAP?
  • What advice would you give to SAP community members or for a someone has just starting out?
  • Have you encountered any particularly creative or unusual organizational structure designs?

entry.title: Material Documents Overview (F1077): Enhancing Features and Usability
entry.content:
Hello SAP users! Let's talk about some updates to the Material Documents Overview app (F1077) and new features designed to close the gaps between the older WebGUI application MB51 and the newer app. We want to thank everyone who shared their experience with the appâ€”it really helps us make things better for you. The following updates are only relevant for the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

Closing Functional Gaps and Enhancing User Experience

SAP is not only working on closing the gaps between MB51 and the Material Documents Overview app but is also enhancing the user experience. The new app is designed to offer a smoother, more intuitive experience that makes it worthwhile to switch. Keep in mind that transitioning to this new app is essential, as the old app will eventually be deprecated.

FAQs Based on Your Feedback

We've gathered some frequently asked questions from customer feedback and are happy to answer them here:

Q: How can I add and arrange more columns and filter options?

A: Click the â€œSettingsâ€ icon at the top of the list report table. Under â€œColumns,â€ enter your search term, like â€œspecial stock type.â€ Check the boxes for the columns you want to add, then click â€œOK.â€ You can drag and drop to arrange columns as you like.

Q: How can I sort the list report?

A: Click the â€œSettingsâ€ icon at the top of the list report table. Then click â€œSortâ€ and pick how you want to sort the data, like by Plant, Storage Location, Material, or Batch. You can save your changes as a variant under "My views," and share it with others if you want.

Q: How can I see values such as Value in local Currency or the Signed quantity?

A: You either select the variant Material Document List with Values or click on setting and add the filter Value in local Currency and or Signed Quantity.

Q: How can I find or create a variant?

A: Select the dropdown menu for â€œSelect Viewâ€ in the top left corner next to the Standard view â€“ choose a predelivered variant to see a different set of fields e. g. â€œMaterial Document List with Valuesâ€.

To create your own variant, add the filters that you want to the list view by clicking on the settings icon for the table. Select your filters and choose OK. If you want, you can also change the sequence of the columns by dragging and dropping them into place. When you have the columns arranged how you wish, click on the dropdown menu arrow for 'Select View' next to Standard and select Save As. Give your variant view a name and choose Save.

Q: Where can I find the Document Header Text or Reference field?

The Document Header Text field can be selected via the settings. The Reference field is called Delivery Note in the new app, and you can also find it via the settings. Both fields are available on the material document's detail page under the "General Information" section.

Q: Where can I see the complete set of information for a stock transfer including the issuing and receiving party?

A: In your filter bar, select filter "Include Auto-Created Item (Transfer)" and set it to "yes". You will then see two line entries. Alternatively, you can display all transfer related attributes in one line by selecting the according fields labelled with â€œtransferâ€ in the settings menu.

Q: How can I separate material code and description in Excel downloads?

A: Use the â€œExportâ€ icon and choose â€œExport as.â€ Then select your format and destination. Make sure to check the â€œSplit cells with multiple valuesâ€ box before you click â€œExport.â€ Your Excel file will then have separate columns for material descriptions and codes.

Wrap-Up

Weâ€™re focused on not only making the Material Documents Overview app better by addressing functional gaps but also improving the overall user experience. Your input is really important in helping us improve, and making the switch to the new app will ensure you're ready for when the old app is phased out.

Keep an eye on the official roadmap for more updates, and let us know your thoughts in the comments. Feel free to reach out with any questions. Thanks for being a part of this journey!

entry.title: Migrate Your SAP Landscape Onto Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Gurus,

i wanna to share with you today a dilemma topics regarding SAP migration onto the Cloud. The question today isn't if you should move your SAP landscape to the cloud or not, but HOW? to do it strategically and efficiently.

Your SAP system is the backbone of your business; your finance, your supply chain, your core data. Moving it is a journey that requires expertise, precision, strong methodology and partnership.

Migration Approaches

The 6Rs migration strategy helps you understand and prioritize portfolio and application discovery, planning, change management, and the technical processes involved in migrating your SAP system to the cloud. The 6 Rs represent six strategies listed in the following table that help you plan for your application migrations.

R strategy

Methodology

Rehosting

The application is migrated as is to AWS. This is also called a "lift-and-shift" approach.

Re-platforming

The application is changed or transformed in some aspect as part of its migration to AWS.

Repurchasing

You move to a different application or solution on the cloud.

Refactoring / Reâ€‘architecting

The application is redesigned (for example, itâ€™s converted from a monolithic architecture to microservices) as part of the migration to AWS.

Retiring

The application is retired during migration to AWS.

Retaining

The application isnâ€™t migrated.

The decision tree diagram helps you visualize the end-to-end process, starting from application discovery and moving through each 6 R strategy.

 The three strategies that are specifically applicable for SAP migrations to cloud are Rehosting, Re-platforming and Re-Architect.

  • Rehosting is applicable when you want to move your SAP system AS-IS to the cloud hosting. This type of migration involves minimal change and can be seen as a natural fit for customers who are already running some sort of SAP systems.
  • Re-platforming is applicable when you want to migrate from an anyDB source database (such as IBM DB2, Oracle Database, or SQL Server) to an SAP HANA database.
  • Re-Architect (or Transform) This is the most transformative path. This includes two major scenarios:
    • Greenfield: A clean slate implementation of S/4HANA directly on cloud hosting. This is for complete process redesign.
    • Brownfield: Where you upgrade your existing SAP ECC system to S/4HANA while migrating it to AWS. This keeps your historical data and existing business processes, but modernized.

The Business Imperative Beyond Infrastructure

So why are thousands of companies migrating their mission-critical SAP systems to the cloud? It goes far beyond simply replacing a data center. It's about achieving four core business outcomes:

  1. Cost & TCO Reduction: By shifting to the cloud offerings like pay-as-you-go model, you eliminate the crippling cycle of hardware refreshes. You can easily right-size environments, utilize reserved instances for deep discounts, and drastically reduce your Total Cost of Ownership.
  2. Agility & Innovation: This is where the magic happens. Moving SAP onto cloud gives you immediate access to other cloud services like AI, Machine Learning, IoT, and Advanced Analytics. This allows you to rapidly innovate on top of your core SAP data in ways that were impossible on-premise.
  3. Performance & Scalability: cloud hosting usually offers the largest, most powerful certified instances for SAP ERP. This means faster reports, quicker transaction processing, and the ability to instantly scale up for month-end closes or peak demand periods, and then scale back down to save cost.
  4. Security & Resilience: all cloud hosting providers, provides a foundational security layer that is unparalleled, and our architecture ensures high availability, disaster recovery, and compliance, giving your teams peace of mind.

End-to-End Migration From Strategy to Success

 The methodology is a robust, four-phase framework; Assess, Mobilize, Migrate, and Optimize, it's designed to de-risk your entire journey.

  1. Assess: We begin with a deep dive. A discovery workshop, a complete inventory of your SAP landscape, and defining non-functional requirements like Recovery Point Objectives/Recovery Time Objectives. The goal is to produce a precise, tailored architecture and cost model. Conduct transfer knowledge sessions with internal team to be able to operate the SAP landscape on the cloud.
  2. Mobilize: This is the planning and preparation stage. We conduct technical validation, create a detailed migration plan, execute all prerequisites checks, and importantly, on-board and upskill your teams, ensuring a smooth transition of ownership post-migration.
  3. Migrate: The execution phase. We utilize best-in-class tools and zero-downtime techniques where possible, ensuring business continuity throughout the process.
  4. Optimize: This is continuous value realization. We move from just running SAP to reducing cost through rightsizing, minimizing future risk, and increasing organizational agility by leveraging cloud services.

The benefits are clear: Reduce TCO, Minimize Risk, Increase Agility, and Innovate. We measure our success not by the project completion date, but by the realization of these benefits in your business.

Targeted Business Outcomes of Migrating SAP to Cloud

 This figure shows the full scope of business outcomes you can achieve once your core SAP systems are modernized on the cloud. Think of your SAP data flowing seamlessly into the cloud, unlocking potential in every direction:

  • Cost Reduction & Data Center Retirement: The immediate, tangible saving by eliminating technical debt and shifting from CaPx to OpEx.
  • Performance & Auto-scaling: Dramatically faster operations and environments that automatically adjust to workload, guaranteeing peak performance during critical business cycles.
  • Agility and Staff Productivity: By offloading infrastructure management to our managed services, your highly skilled IT staff can dedicate their time to high-value projects, not maintenance.
  • Digital Transformation (SAP S/4HANA): This infrastructure is the perfect foundation for a future S/4HANA transformation, leveraging the speed of HANA and the elasticity of cloud hosting.
  • Data and Analytics: The critical ability to integrate your SAP data with the vast array of cloud analytical tools like SAC, Amazon Redshift or MS PowerBI, to gain deep, competitive business insights and complex data science applications.
  • Improved Security and Resilience: A globally secure and highly available platform that meets stringent compliance requirements.
  • Industry Solutions: With SAP migration onto cloud, you will not just benefit from cloud hosting or cloud services only; but you will gain the benefit of utilize a lot of business solution that leverage your business operations and streamline your business applications platform and all are running onto cloud and integrates together to leverage your business performance and efficiency.

Hope my thoughts useful for you and guide you to the right decision ğŸ‘

thank you all and wish you a smooth and successful migration.

entry.title: Financial Planned Data in Professional Services â€“ by Project Financial Booklet
entry.content:
In this blog post we will explain how the plan categories are used in the customer project scenario tailored for professional services. We will also explain how the plan data is calculated and updated in ACDOCP, and how they can be reported with the Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Services app.

enjoy

Chenchu Zhong and Stefan Walz

In customer project management, staying on top of budgets and costs is essential for ensuring profitability and meeting client expectations, especially in fixed-price billing scenarios. Multiple planning versions help monitor the original plan and track changes that arise from resource allocation or scope adjustments. Additionally, we use the financial plan data for the POC calculation in Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR). In the Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Services app, we have enabled the display of all planned data versions for customer projects, ensuring full visibility and transparency. In this blog post, weâ€™ll explain what each plan category means, and which is updated in ACDOCP. We will explain the calculations and applications of planned data in the project-based services scenario, including Baseline Planned Data (PRO01), Ongoing Planned Data (PRO02), EAC Planned Data (PRO03), EBRR Planned Data (REVREC01), Manual Plan Category, and Virtual Plan Category.

Letâ€™s use a fixed-price customer project as our example, where multiple planning data versions may be available to track and manage costs.

Baseline Planned Data

CPM Baseline planned data (Plan category PRO01) represents a snapshot of the initial project plan that records the contract conditions under which the project was started.

This version is technically created when the project moves to the â€œIn Executionâ€ stage.

Ongoing Planned Data

CPM Ongoing planned data (Plan category PRO02) reflects the current planning adjustment of the project. During the execution phase, project managers can update planned resources and expenses using the Plan Customer Projects app, which then updates the ongoing planned data. To ensure the ongoing planned data is reflected in financials, it is important to select â€œSync with Financeâ€ under the â€œVersionâ€ tab.

In the project example, the baseline planned data matches the ongoing planned data (referred to as â€œcurrentâ€), as no changes have been made to the ongoing planned version.

Figure 1 Manual ACDOCP update of baseline planned data and ongoing planned data in the Plan Customer Projects app

By choosing â€œSync with Financeâ€, the ongoing planned data is updated in financials (ACDOCP). In the Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Services app, both the baseline planned data, and ongoing planned data can be viewed.

Figure 2 Display baseline planned data and ongoing planned data in the Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Services app

The service cost rate is maintained by the overhead accountant in the Manage Cost Rate â€“ Services app. The cost rates are determined for each resource plan item by the company code/ service org, the role/activity type, work item, or PERNR if assigned.

The time planning is done based on role/activity type. The hours are distributed by the system over the months the project is running. This distribution can be adjusted manually. The system derives the cost rate for each planning period and calculates the amount by multiplied hours of the period with the cost rate of the period.

The plan data in the customer project application are always shown in the project currency. If there is an own project currency applied for the project which deviates from the company code currency, or if there are cost rates maintained in a different currency because intercompany resources are planned, there is a currency conversion done with a monthly P rate occurs by default. However, you can change the currency conversion type in the configuration of the plan category.

The plan revenue is determined in the fixed price project by the billing plan amount.

CPM application sends the data to ACDOCP with transaction currency = project currency. If there is a conversion required, at least for group currency, then ACDOCP converts with a monthly P rate (default configuration in plan categories)

EAC Planned Data

CPM EAC planned data (plan category PRO03), is an estimated total cost of a project on completion, combining actual costs incurred to date with forecasts for remaining effort and expenditures.

While baseline and ongoing plan only take the resource planning into account, the EAC calculation considers deviations between actual and plan.

  • Key Components:
    • Actual Costs (AC): What has been spent so far (read from ACDOCA)
    • Estimate to Completion (ETC): Projected costs to complete tasks still in progress.
    • Estimate at Completion (EAC): Actual Costs (AC) + Estimate to Completion (ETC).
  • Calculation:
    • Actual Costs (AC) = read from ACDOA, no calculation
    • Estimate to Completion (ETC)

The ETC calculation works the following:

  1. First planned costs in project currency are calculated:
    The planned quantity per period is multiplied with the cost rate per period.
    If the cost rate currency is different to the project currency, the currency conversion is done with P rate, which is valid at the beginning of the period.
  2. Then calculate the ETC cost based on customer project data as follows:
    (Planned Hours-Actual Hours) / Planned Hours Ã— Planned Cost in Project Currency
  3. Remark: this is done for each expense type

The actuals are read from ACDOCA. To get plan costs in project currency, the object currency is read.

See https://me.sap.com/notes/3547953/E for details on how ETC and EAC calculation works.

The calculated EAC will be different to the original CPM plan, if the following occurs:

  1. You record more than the total planned hours allocated for the planned activity type/role (This applies regardless of who logged the hours, as along as they belong to the planned activity type)
  2. Hours are logged under an unplanned/unassigned activity type/role, work item, or service organization
  3. Post unplanned expenses, e.g., travel expenses

In the Review Customer Projects app, the project manager can adjust the ETC values based on forecasted efforts (quantities) required to complete the project.

For the example project, the junior consultant has already recorded 5 hours of work, resulting in actual costs of 5 hours multiplied by the service cost rate of 50 EUR/h, equating to 250 EUR. The ETC quantity for the junior consultant is currently 5 hours based on the current plan.

Figure 3 Review EAC values in the app Review Customer Projects

However, the project manager reassesses the situation and determines that the 5 hours allocated for the junior consultant are insufficient to finish the remaining task. As a result, the project manager updates the ETC for the junior consultant from 5 hours to 8 hours. With the updated ETC, the EAC quantity for the junior consultant increases from 10 hours to 13 hours, resulting in the EAC costs increasing from 500 EUR to 650 EUR.

Figure 4 Adjust EAC values in the app â€œReview Customer Projectsâ€

To update the EAC values in Financials (ACDOCP), the project manager uses the Transfer Project Forecast app to schedule a recurring job to update the EAC values for ongoing projects.

Remark on the planned revenue: their calculation is done dependent on the contract type. For a fixed price project plan revenue is taken from billing plan. In the case of T&E billing, billing simulation is carried out to determine the planned revenues based on the EAC costs.

Figure 5 Transfer Project Forecast to Finance

The job has been successfully executed for the example project. The updated forecasting data can now be reviewed in the Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Services app.

Figure 6 Display EAC planned data in the app Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Services

For customer projects, the planned data (baseline, ongoing, EAC, EBRR) is consistently updated within the leading ledger. Consequently, in the Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Service app, the planned data can be viewed by selecting the leading ledger in the global filter.

The plan category PRO03 serves as the source for the planned data related to the revenue recognition key SPTMSR for the T&E billing &PoC-based revenue recognition method. Please refer to the blog post: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/customer-projects-with-t-amp-e-billing-amp-poc-based-revenue-recognition/ba-p/13771327 for more details.

EBRR Planned Data

EBRR planned data (plan category REVREC01) represents the planned/EAC data/, which was used in Event-Based Revenue Recognition period-end calculation. When you run period-end close or you use the EBRR monitor app and save the revalued data, this plan category is updated with the used plan amounts for the selected period.

While the 3 plan categories shown above have always only one amount (as previous plan updates are deleted with a new plan update) the EBRR plan data is  kept per period. This allows you to analyze which EAC data was used for a previous period-end calculation.

In this example, the project uses the revenue recognition key SPFC, which applies the fixed-price, cost-based percentage-of-completion (POC) method. In the configuration activity Maintain Settings for Event-Based Revenue Recognition (ID 102530), the planned data source is set to strategy 306.

This means that Event-based EBRR uses EAC data only if there was an update in the Review Customer Project app (confirmed EAC), otherwise the current CPM plan data are read, and no ACDOCP entries are used.

At period-end EBRR uses the dynamic EAC by simulating the functionality of the Review Customer Project app. In which cases dynamic EAC can differ to original CPM plan see above. If there was an update in the Review Customer Project app, this is taken.

Figure 7 Source for Plan Values in the Configuration Activity Maintain Settings for Event-Based Revenue Recognition (ID 102530)

According to the configuration, in this example the real-time event-based revenue recognition is calculated using the confirmed EAC from the CPM planning applications (1150 EUR). Selecting â€œRevalueâ€ recalculates the recognized revenue based on the dynamic EAC costsâ€”which in this example equals the confirmed EACâ€”and is 1300 EUR.

Figure 8 Revalue in the Event-Based Revenue Recognition â€“ Projects app

Additionally, the first revaluation creates an EBRR planned data snapshot (plan category REVREC01). This snapshot is updated at each revaluation / period-end closing to capture the latest dynamic EAC for period-end closing calculations. The planned data is updated in the Event-Based Revenue Recognition â€“ Projects app.

Figure 9 EBRR Planned Data in the Event-Based Revenue Recognition â€“ Projects app

The EBRR planned data is now visible in the Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Services app as . During the revaluation or period-end closing, EBRR posts the delta of the EAC to the corresponding period of the revaluation/period-end close. In the Event-Based Revenue Recognition â€“ Projects app, the aggregated value is always displayed. In the Project Financial Booklet, you can choose to view data up to the current period or leave the periods unselected to see the aggregated EBRR planned data.

Figure 10 Display EBRR Planned Data in the Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Services app

Manual Planned Data

The plan categories above are calculated by the system based on the resource planning and billing information. With 2502 you can create an own plan category for projects. The manual planned data is characterized by the fact that it is recorded based on cost elements without reference to resource planning. They can be recorded in the SAP S/4HANA system by the Import Financial Plan Data app, through API or by transfer from SAC.

The manual plan category can we created in configuration activity (ID 101970)

Figure 11 Configuration for manual plan category

Usage 4 allows a manual planning.

With the assignment of application type â€œProject Managementâ€, the following additional checks and derivation logic are provided during the update in ACDOCP:

  • A WBS element must be provided for every planning line item. This prevents an accidental deletion of planned data provided for other projects, which can happen when you use a periodic plan category like PLN.
  • The account assignment type â€œWBS elementâ€ is determined for all planning line items. This leads to subsequent derivation of additional attributes from the project and the assigned sales order item. For example, the profit center from the WBS billing element and the margin analysis fields from the sales order item are derived and stored for the planning line items.

Recommendation: use for your manual planning an own plan category with application type â€œproject managementâ€ , and not a periodic plan category like PLN.

When you use the import app, you must provide a CSV File, which you can see here:

Figure 12 File for plan data import

The columns with the X in line 3 define the plan data scope: these fields must be filled, otherwise you get an error, and the plan data cannot be updated. Additional this is the scope, which is checked for project plan categories: if an X is missing, the import is rejected.

 You can define the fiscal year and period, and you can select company code or transaction currency. The currencies that are not provided, including global currency and object currency, are determined and translated by the ACDCOP update. The exchange rate type is defined in the plan category (see above) and the currency date is the first of the entered period.

For a project in a foreign currency,  you can enter the plan data in a transaction currency that is equal to the project currency.

 When using plan data in EBRR you need at least one revenue and one expense/cost G/L account line item. In the configuration activity Maintain Settings for Event-Based Revenue Recognition, you can set this custom plan category as the source of planned values for EBRR processing (source 500) for the allowed cost-based POC revenue recognition keys.

In the Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Services app, use the page filter to select your custom planning category, then add the measures Planned Revenue Manual, Planned Cost Manual, and Planned Margin Manual to display the externally imported planned data for customer projects.

Figure 13 Display Imported Planned Data in the Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Services app

Virtual Plan Category

For aggregation of the amount of several plan categories you can use a virtual plan category

Figure 14 Configuration for virtual plan category

There is an own application type â€œ8 Virtual plan categoryâ€ available.

In configuration you can assign the plan categories to the virtual plan category (config ID 106876)

Figure 15 Configuration for assigning plan categories to virtual plan category

Please note there are no ACDOCP entries for the virtual plan category! You can enter the virtual plan category in the reporting as plan category: the report will read all assigned plan categories and aggregate the values. Additional you can assign the virtual plan category in EBRR as source for plan.

The virtual plan category could help you to move from periodic plan category PLN to a manual project plan category.

Conclusion

 Understanding and effectively monitoring planned data across various plan categories is essential for driving successful customer projects. In this blog, we have outlined the definitions, calculations, and currency conversions for key plan categories, including Baseline Planned Data (PRO01), Ongoing Planned Data (PRO02), EAC Planned Data (PRO03), EBRR Planned Data (REVREC01), Manual Plan Category, and Virtual Plan Category. By leveraging the Project Financial Booklet â€“ Professional Services app, you can gain enhanced visibility across planning versions, enabling better budget control, profitability tracking, and alignment of plans with actuals.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.2: Final What's New & Product Assistance available
entry.content:
With immediate effect, the final What's New information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.2 is now available.

To access the final Whatâ€™s New information, please use the Whatâ€™s New Viewer. In addition, the final Product Assistance (aka Application Help) for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.2 is available. Please use the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Help Portal page to access it.

entry.title: SAP S4 HANA Finance integration and Use case with SAP Joule
entry.content:
What Is SAP Joule?

SAP Joule is SAPâ€™s AI copilot embedded across its cloud applications. It offers four interaction typesâ€”Transactional, Navigational, Informational, and Analyticalâ€”that let users perform business tasks via natural language within SAP environments. It understands user context, roles, permissions, and remains secure by design. It can also ground responses in your own business documents.

 How SAP Joule works in Public vs. Private Cloud is one of the most important considerations for finance teams (especially in FICO) deciding on adoption.

Hereâ€™s a structured view:

 SAP Joule in Public vs. Private Cloud

Deployment & Integration

  • Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)
    • Joule is natively embedded and updated by SAP automatically.
    • Integration with SAP FICO apps (GL, AP, AR, Asset Accounting, Controlling) is out of the box.
    • No additional installation required - users just activate and configure.
  • Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)
    • Joule can be enabled, but may require additional setup and integration.
    • Some Joule features might lag behind public cloud, because public gets innovations first.
    • Still integrates with FICO, but might require extra configuration & tenant connections to SAP BTP.

Feature Availability

  • Public Cloud
    • Joule supports all 4 interaction types (Transactional, Navigational, Informational, Analytical) directly in Fiori apps.
    • Example in FICO: â€œPost vendor invoiceâ€ â†’ transaction executes directly.
    • Faster delivery of Joule Agents and Joule Studio.
  • Private Cloud
    • Informational & Analytical features available early (queries, reports, insights).
    • Transactional flows may require enablement through custom skills/agents.
    • Joule Studio can still be connected via SAP BTP, but adoption speed depends on customerâ€™s upgrade cycle.

Customization & Extensibility

  • Public Cloud
    • Limited custom codingâ€”extensions must go through SAP BTP side-by-side development.
    • Joule skills/agents are mostly standardized.
    • Great if you want speed & standardization.
  • Private Cloud
    • More flexibility: you can create custom FICO processes, reports, and Joule agents.
    • Easier to integrate with on-prem or legacy systems.
    • Suited for companies with complex finance processes.

Data Security & Residency

  • Public Cloud
    • Data is hosted on SAP-managed hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, GCP, SAP DCs).
    • Joule queries financial data via secure APIs; customers rely on SAPâ€™s compliance.
  • Private Cloud
    • You control hosting, location, and more of the security stack.
    • Some finance-heavy industries (banking, defense, public sector) may prefer this for regulatory reasons.

Upgrade & Innovation

  • Public Cloud
    • Quarterly upgrades â†’ Joule features arrive first and fastest.
    • Example: New Joule Agents for FICO tasks (like dispute resolution) appear immediately.
  • Private Cloud
    • Annual upgrades (with optional Feature Packs).
    • Joule features arrive laterâ€”innovation follows public cloud by a few cycles.

 Comparison Table

Aspect

Public Cloud

Private Cloud

Availability

Native, out-of-the-box

Needs setup, later adoption

Updates

Quarterly, fastest innovations

Annual/controlled upgrades

Customization

Limited, BTP-based

Flexible, deep customizations

Security

SAP-managed hyperscalers

Customer-controlled

FICO Use Cases

Immediate transactional & analytical support

Strong for complex, regulated finance scenarios

Joule Studio

Fully available

Available via BTP, more flexible

 Which is Better for FICO?

  • Public Cloud â†’ Best if you want rapid innovation, standard finance processes, faster AI adoption.
  • Private Cloud â†’ Best if you need deep customization, strict compliance, hybrid IT integration.

 SAP Joule version requirements for S/4HANA Cloud editions (Public and Private):

  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Joule arrived as part of the Public Cloud starting around Q3 2024, and is embedded in all releases thereafter, including 2408 (August 2024) and onward.
  • While Joule is built into these releases, you still need proper entitlement and authorization to use it; this may require activation via your SAP admin or account executive.
  • There are setup guides available detailing how to activate Joule once entitlement is granted.

In Summary:

If your system is on Public Cloud release 2408 (Aug 2024) or later, Joule is already supportedâ€”assuming you've got the right access and permissions.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

  • Joule is available in the Private Cloud as well, but requires setup and configuration. It's not automatically activeâ€”you must enable it via SAP BTP and Joule Studio.
  • Technical prerequisites include ensuring the UI5 version in your system meets or exceeds the minimum required for Joule integration. The specific UI5 version will depend on your release; you can consult SAP documentation for exact details.

In Summary:

Private Cloud systems can support Jouleâ€”but you must set it up, ensure the UI5 stack is compatible, and configure the feature via BTP.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise (Classic)

  • Joule is not supported on on-premise S/4HANA. SAP has confirmed it's not on the current roadmap for classic on-premise systems.
  • Thereâ€™s a planned strategyâ€”possibly coming Q1 2025â€”to enable Joule via SAP Build Work Zone, BTP, and Joule Studio even for on-prem systems. But as of now, Joule remains unavailable on-prem and unsupported.

High-Level Overview

Edition

Supported from (release)

Requirements

Public Cloud

2408 (Aug 2024) onward

Needs entitlement/authorization & activation

Private Cloud

Post-2024 releases

Requires UI5 prerequisites + BTP/Joule Studio setup

On-Premise (classic)

Not supported (as of now)

No Joule availability; roadmap may include future BTP-based solution

Summary:

  • Public Cloud: Joule is supported starting with 2408 onwardâ€”activate it via entitlement.
  • Private Cloud: Joule is available but not automaticâ€”requires UI compliance + setup via BTP.
  • On-Premise: Joule is not supported yet; no built-in version availability.

Hereâ€™s how SAP Joule, SAPâ€™s generative AI assistant, can be applied specifically within the SAP FICO (Finance & Controlling) domain:

SAP Joule Application in FICO

  • Transactional Interactions

Joule allows users to perform CRUD operations and manage financial documents via natural languageâ€”imagine asking:

  • â€œPost a vendor invoice of $5,000 to account X with due date Y.â€
  • â€œShow me the status of PO invoice 10234.â€
    While SAP hasn't yet released out-of-the-box FICO conversational flows, Jouleâ€™s transactional model supports this kind of interaction across cloud applications.
  • Navigational Interactions

Instead of navigating through menus to reach Fiori apps like â€œDisplay GL Account Balances,â€ you could simply ask:

  • â€œWhere can I review G/L balances?â€
    Joule will direct you to the relevant screen.
  • Informational Interactions

Straight answers instead of digging through help docs. You can ask:

  • â€œWhatâ€™s the difference between cost center and profit center accounting?â€
  • â€œExplain account determination for automatic postings.â€
    Joule will deliver concise explanations, referencing SAP documentation or your own policy documents.

Analytical Interactions

Joule bridges your natural-language queries to data analytics:

  • â€œShow me quarterly expense trends per cost center.â€
  • â€œWhich cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?â€
    It returns charts, metrics, or dashboardsâ€”leveraging SAP Analytics Cloud integration.

Advanced: Joule Agents & Studio

Joule Agents

SAP has introduced AI agentsâ€”autonomous actors capable of executing complex, multi-step workflows across business functions. In FICO, custom agents could:

  • Automate dispute resolution: Collaborate across finance and service teams to validate discrepancies and propose corrections.
  • Cash collection workflows: Analyze overdue invoices, coordinate with collections, and initiate follow-ups.
    These agents are part of SAPâ€™s cross-functional automation strategy.

Joule Studio (within SAP Build)

No-code/low-code tool to create custom skills or agents tailored for your FICO needs:

  • Build a skill to automatically generate internal financial reports, or trigger approval workflows.
  • Automate vendor reconciliation or recurring postings by designing tailored AI agents.
    These skills and agents integrate across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Summary Table

Joule Capability

FICO Use Case Example

Transactional

Post invoices, check payment status via natural language

Navigational

Ask â€œWhere to view Cost Center Reports?â€

Informational

Clarify financial terms or posting rules

Analytical

Generate trends and KPI charts using SAC

Agents & Studio

Automate dispute resolution, cash collection, approvals

Key Benefits in FICO

  • Boost Productivity: Save time by speaking instead of clicking through screens.
  • Reduce Errors: Leverage conversational clarity and auto-generated documents.
  • Improve Insights: Conduct data reviews and root cause analysis through simple dialogue.
  • Automate Complex Workflows: Agents handle multi-step tasks such as reconciliations or approvals automatically.

Real-World Usage Context -- Caveats

While SAP is rapidly developing Jouleâ€™s capabilities, many implementations remain in pilot or PoC stages. Users in forums report limited early usage, primarily for basic navigation or queries.

Here are concrete FICO scenarios where you could pilot SAP Joule and even extend it with Joule Agents / Studio:

 Pilot Scenarios in SAP FICO

  1. Invoice & Payment Handling
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œPost an invoice for vendor ABC with $12,000 due in 30 days.â€
  • Joule Action: Creates the posting, validates tax code, and confirms with you.
  • Extension with Agent: Automate follow-upâ€”if payment not cleared by due date, Joule Agent triggers a reminder email or escalates.
  1. Month-End Close Assistant
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œWhat are the pending tasks for month-end close?â€
  • Joule Action: Lists open items (accruals, GR/IR clearing, reconciliations).
  • Extension with Agent: Automate recurring accrual postings and send alerts to approvers who are late in providing confirmations.
  1. Financial Analysis & Insights
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œShow me expense trend per cost center for last 6 months.â€
  • Joule Action: Returns a chart (via SAC integration).
  • Extension with Agent: Forecast next quarterâ€™s expenses and flag cost centers that may exceed budgets.
  1. Audit & Compliance Checks
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œList journal entries above $50,000 in the last quarter without approvals.â€
  • Joule Action: Generates a filtered list.
  • Extension with Agent: Create an automated internal audit agent that periodically checks for compliance exceptions and notifies controllers.
  1. Treasury & Cash Management
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œWhat is todayâ€™s cash position?â€
  • Joule Action: Summarizes bank balances, incoming/outgoing payments.
  • Extension with Agent: Auto-generate a daily treasury dashboard at 9 AM and send to CFO.
  1. Dispute & Collections Management
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œShow me customers with invoices overdue > 60 days.â€
  • Joule Action: Lists overdue accounts.
  • Extension with Agent: An AI agent sends personalized payment reminders and schedules calls with collections staff.
  1. Budget vs. Actual Control
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œWhich cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?â€
  • Joule Action: Shows variances with drill-down.
  • Extension with Agent: Automatically notify budget owners when variances exceed a threshold (say 10%).

 How to Design in Joule Studio

In Joule Studio (within SAP Build) you can:

  1. Create a Skill â†’ â€œGenerate quarterly P&L by company code and send PDF to finance team.â€
  2. Create an Agent â†’ â€œMonitor overdue vendor payments and auto-initiate dunning.â€
  3. Connect Non-SAP Apps â†’ e.g., send approvals via MS Teams or Slack.

 

 This way, Joule moves from a copilot (answering queries) to a colleague (executing finance tasks for you).

 

Deep Dive on one of the real-world example: Vendor Invoice Posting with SAP Joule in Public vs Private Cloud.

 Example: Vendor Invoice Posting with Joule

 Scenario

A finance user wants to post a vendor invoice for Vendor 300012, amount $12,000, due in 30 days.

 Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
    â€œPost a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.
  • Joule Process:
    1. Understands the intent (â€œCreate Vendor Invoiceâ€).
    2. Pulls relevant master data (Vendor 300012 details, tax code, payment terms).
    3. Pre-fills the invoice screen in Fiori.
    4. User confirms â†’ Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Public Cloud:
    • Joule can immediately display the document number and due date schedule.
    • If connected to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), Joule can also show how this impacts cash outflow forecast.
    • Minimal setup â†’ available out-of-the-box.

 Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
     â€œPost a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.â€
  • Joule Process:
    • Provide navigation â†’ â€œOpen FB60 (Vendor Invoice Entry)â€ or â€œFiori App: Create Supplier Invoice.â€
    • Pre-fill metadata only if integrated with custom Joule Skill via Joule Studio.
    1. Joule recognizes intent, but instead of direct posting, it may:
    2. User manually confirms or adjusts in the classic posting screen (e.g., FB60 / MIRO).
    3. Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Private Cloud:
    • You can customize Joule Agent (via Joule Studio + BTP) to enforce company-specific validations (e.g., block invoices >$10,000 without 2 approvals).
    • Joule can connect to legacy non-SAP apps (like OCR invoice scanners or in-house workflow systems).
    • Requires more setup & governance compared to Public Cloud.

 Side-by-Side Comparison

Step

Key Takeaway:

  • In Private Cloud, Joule = control + flexibility â†’ better if you need extra compliance steps, custom posting logic, or hybrid integration.

entry.title: Index-Based Asset Revaluation in Argentina with SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Understanding Index-Based Asset Revaluation

In Argentina, companies must periodically revalue their fixed assets to reflect inflationary changes. SAP's new feature automates this process, ensuring compliance with local regulations. By using the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app, businesses can create and manage revaluation indices, which are then applied to asset master records for accurate valuation. When Depreciation Posting runs, the depreciation area will also post the revaluation by the Index registered (if it was assigned in the Fixed Asset Master Data)â€ in the Manage Monthly Closing Activities section.

Prerequisites

To be able to post a revaluation in a specific depreciation area, revaluation must be allowed in the depreciation area. SAP has defined for each depreciation area in the predefined configuration whether revaluation is allowed.

Step 1: Maintain Asset Revaluation Index

1. Open the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app.

2. Choose Create and specify the following details:

   - Revaluation Index ID: Freely selectable (independent of a specific company code)

   - Index Type: Replacement Value, Monthly

4. Choose Continue.

5. On the Asset Revaluation Index page, in the Header section, specify values for all mandatory (*) fields, such as Index Description, Country/Region Key, and Currency

6. In the Index Items section, specify the index values such as the Valid To dates. The system automatically sets the Valid From dates.

7. Choose Create.

 At this point, the indexâ€™s lifecycle status is Created.

8. Choose Activate to make the index available for valuation views.

The indexâ€™s lifecycle status changes to Active.
For more information: see Maintain Asset Revaluation Index | SAP Help Portal

Step 2: Create Asset Master Record

You can use the Manage Fixed Assets app (F3425) to create and view asset master records and display asset values for each valuation.

You can create a new fixed asset from scratch, or you can use an existing fixed asset as a template. For more information on Manage Fixed Assets app (F3425), please refer to Manage Fixed Assets | SAP Help Portal

For more information on how to create asset master data, please refer to Creating Fixed Asset Master Data | SAP Help Portal

 Post Asset Acquisition

1. Open the Post Asset Acquisition app.

2. Choose Post > Post Acquisition > Acquisition (Net).

3. Specify all the mandatory values.

4. Choose Simulate to simulate the accounting posting.

5. Choose the expand icon to display all ledgers.
For more details on the Post Asset Acquisition app, see
Post Asset Acquisition - And Quantity Adjustment | SAP Help Portal

View Journal Entries

1. In the Post Asset Acquisition app, go to the Journal Entries tab, choose the document number of the journal entry, and then choose Display Journal Entries â€“ New Version.

The system navigates to the Display Journal Entries app.

2. Go to the Line Items tab and choose T-Account View.

The accounting postings are displayed in the Display Journal Entries â€“ In T-Account View app.

For more details, see Display Journal Entries â€“ In T-Account View | SAP Help Portal

View Revaluations for the Fixed Asset

1. Open the Manage Fixed Assets app.

2. Search for and open the fixed asset that you created in Step 2.

3. On the Valuation tab, click the small right arrow to choose the depreciation area for which you want to view the revaluations.

4. Display the values by fiscal year or currency, as required.

This section acts as the "Fixed Asset Explorer", where the values are displayed at different times of the fiscal year.

5. Choose Explain Key Figures for information on the displayed values.

6. Go to the Journal Entries tab to view all documents posted in this depreciation area for this asset. These values can be displayed by fiscal year and currency.

7. Go to the Depreciation tab to view ordinary and revaluated depreciations for different fiscal periods.

Manage Monthly Closing Activities

1. Open the Schedule Asset Accounting Jobs app.

2. Choose Create.

3. Choose the job template Depreciation Posting Run and choose Step 2.

4. Set a schedule for the job to run and choose Step 3.5. To schedule and run the job, choose Schedule.

6. Choose the job and download the results.

View the depreciation values in the Manage Fixed Assets app.

For more details, see Schedule Asset Accounting Jobs | SAP Help Portal

Reporting: Reporting | SAP Help Portal

1. Use the Asset Accounting Overview app to access key information and KPIs within the Asset Accounting area, and gain insight into current trends.

2. Use the Asset Balances app to display balances of fixed assets according to various criteria, such as company code, depreciation area, segment, or profit center.

3. Use the Asset Transactions app to check and evaluate daily or monthly operations in Asset Accounting by listing asset transactions posted to the general ledger.

4. Use the Depreciation Lists app as a supplement to the profit and loss statement.

5. Use the Asset History Sheet app to display the asset history sheet, which shows value changes to the fixed asset balances in a fiscal year for a depreciation area.

Summary

The explained process of revaluation by indexes allows to cover the basic cases of the inflation adjustment process for fixed assets in Argentina means a simpler way. Additionally, the complex and non-common cases could be supported by extensibility.

entry.title: Overhead costs in Maintenance Orders, Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Collaborative effort of Saurabh Goyal.

Overhead costs in maintenance refer to the indirect expenses associated with keeping assets, equipment, facilities, or infrastructure operational, but that are not directly tied to a specific maintenance task or job.

Why it matters?

  • Maintenance overheads affect the total cost of ownership of equipment.
  • Businesses need to track and allocate these costs accurately to understand true operational expenses.
  • Understanding overhead costs helps in making decisions on repair vs. replace, outsourcing, or investing in predictive maintenance tools.

This blog outlines the necessary process and configuration required to perform this calculation in the public cloud. It also highlights the associated constraints and provides guidance for customers and partners on how to proceed.

Define Costing Sheet (SSCUI 102922 Define Costing Sheets )

Define the material overhead rates for corresponding plant actual /planned

Planning Costing SheetProduction Costing Sheet

Configuration of the assignment costing sheet to valuation variant (SSCUI 102607 :Define Valuation Variants for Material Cost Estimates)

Assign planning costing sheet to valuation variant 006 and production costing sheet to valuation variant 007

Configure Overhead Costs value category for maintenance Order (SSCUI 103792 Maintain Value Categories)

Configure Value category for Maintenance orders. Create a new value category for Overhead costs

Assign relevant Cost element group to newly created value category (SSCUI 103806:Assign Cost Elements to Value Categories)

Overhead calculation as per costing sheet

As you create maintenance order, add material to operation and save, the planned overhead costs are calculated and same is reflected in the costs tab in Overhead costs value category.

In the backend the costing sheet is filled with the costing sheet which we assigned in the configuration SSCUI 102607 above as maintenance order is assigned with costing sheet.

In the below maintenance order we created, the material value is 120000 EUR and corresponding overhead costs according to the overhead rate 7% in the costing sheet will be 0.07*120000 = 8400 EUR

Planned costs updated under cost category overhead costs

Goods issue on the maintenance order

Goods Issue

Run overhead calculation actual

Material Overhead costs calculated

The same is reflected in actual costs for overhead cost category in the maintenance order

Actual overhead costs reflection on Maintenance Order

As illustrated in the scenario above, configuring the costing sheet within the valuation variant enables the business to calculate overhead costs effectively. However, this approach does come with certain limitations, which are outlined in the section below.

Constraints to the process:

  • Since the field is hidden, the process cannot be altered during runtime.

Available options:

  • Assignment of costing sheet to maintenance order type. Customer / partner can vote to the CIP request https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/333625
  • For additional features, new request can be raised.
